I was introduced to this as a fun twist on the typical "Typing Simulator" game. Something that would be different from  the classic, railroaded -Type-Well-To-Shoot-Stuff- style you would find in "The Typing of the Dead", or similar titles. 

Oh boy, what a fun and refreshing twist this is. This isn't some heroic battle, typing to defend humanity from an undead evil or alien onslaught. Oh no. Not this game. 

No, in this game you are not a hero with a gun busting down doors to save dramatic damsels. 

You are a worker sitting at a typerwriter who's only job is to type well enough not to die.

That means typing better than your neighbor. That means typing faster than you thought you were capable of, under pressure that -of course- isn't actually present but is no less perceived despite it's non-existence. 

The soundscape the game drops you into is droning, eerie, with an inexpressible chill that makes each tactile press of keys bouncing around the dark chamber echo in some primal, afraid part of the mind. It's incredible. 

I found myself not just competing with my fellows in the typing chamber, but waging all out war on my own average and personal bests to see them improve. 

I won't spoil all of the best bits ;) go give it a go while it's a demo. 

You won't regret it!

Awesome demo, Final Sentence seems to be setting up to be THE ultimate, competitive, high-stakes typing experience. Definitely needs a little smoothing out around the edges but the bones here are good. 

The atmosphere is dark, dystopian, and immersive. The challenge presented can fluctuate a lot even if you're a good typist; sometimes the prompts are simple, sometimes they're rather complex and finger-twisty. 

Recommendations:

Leaderboard: Promotes competition and game longevity. On a further note, there should be an in-depth stats screen after each game that shows how other players did in that round as well as yourself.

Spectator Mode: The idea of a spectator mode would be way more engaging and interesting if you could either walk around the room (as an invisible entity (or not)) for the remainder of the match or switch to the perspective of the remaining players to actually see how they are typing.

Game Modes: I saw another user suggest alternate game modes such as last-man-standing or team-based and that is an amazing idea. Just anything else that users can play to shake things up after playing a lot of the 'main' game mode.

Customization(?): Seeing as how we can level up I'm assuming we will be unlocking things as we win or play. It would be cool if you could alter how your character looks, possibly your type writer, or your player card. Obviously you would earn these things by winning matches, achieving certain high scores for WPM or accuracy, etc.

Multiplayer: It would be nice if you could load into a public match with a friend or two instead of having to play an entirely private match in order to play with friends.

Prompts: The game should definitely have more prompts. There IS good variety in what is here so far but it can be disappointing to load into several 'De Beers' matches in a row. More passages from literature, other media, and more custom prompts would greatly enhance replayability. 

Anyways, this is an amazing game with a very unique concept; and it's executed very well. Can't wait to see what the full release has in store.

Games like The Textorcist, Blood Typers, or even the classic Typing of the Dead are some great examples of how you can interpret typing as gameplay in creative ways.

[h1]The review[/h1]
I'm a pretty good typer and love typing games, so I decided to give this a shot. I played three times after the tutorial. I forfeited one of these games.

The idea is interesting. The game has potential. The atmosphere and graphics are on point, and the gameplay itself is fun.

But the issue is : if someone is taking a big lead (which happened in my two complete games), you basically have no way to close the gap. And that's because the game has too many "time wasters".

The first time waster, which is the one I think is legit, is making you restart the whole sentence if you make a mistake. It's quick, it's instant, you just waste the time to retype what you already typed.

The second time waster is the mandatory break between section. The total text you have to type is divided in sections, and at the end of each, you have a few seconds where you can't do anything. The sections themselves are fine (they also act as resets for the third time waster), but I think the wait should be removed, or changed. Because said wait seems to be the same for everybody, that prevents you from catching up with the first place.

The third time waster is the worst and should definitelly be removed : the roulette. Each time you make 3 mistakes in one section, you have to play Russian Roulette and risk being eliminated. And the animation *is so damn long*. It feels longer than the mandatory break, you waste so much time, and it makes the gap between you and the others even bigger because it is a wait only those who trigger a roulette suffer. And it feels like a double punishment : you already have to redo the whole line, and then you have to wait super long to be able to get back in the game. The game I forfeited was because I triggered two roulettes so I was basically cooked. In my opinion, the shot should be instant (especially because you can see the guy hold the gun up on your second mistake, so no need to animate him hold the gun up) and not take longer than the line reset when you make a mistake.

In short : because of the mandatory break and the roulette, once someone has one or two sections in advance on you, you pretty much lost. Fighting knowing you have no chance to win is not fun. Better forfeit and start a new lobby than waste time.

As such, even though I love the concept and I see efforts have been poured into this project, I cannot recommend this game in this state.

[h1]Suggestions[/h1]

My first suggestion is to remove the mandatory break and the roulette animation. Just have the black coat man fire immediately without a pause. It will remove some of the drama of the roulette triggering when it's a blank, but it won't remove the shock of being shot if it's a live round and right now it's more frustrating than scary.

My second suggestion is to remove the snowball effect of taking the lead : the leader has too much leeway.
Maybe make it so everyone has to wait each others at the end of each section, so the next section starts with everyone at the same point, and add a bullet to the bottom 50% players' roulette. That way, you still insentize everyone to be one of the quickest as to not get rouletted, which keeps the stress high and still pushes them to make mistake and trigger the roulette, while not having someone who's so obviously in the lead that people cannot catch up. It could be a second play mode, with the current one being a "Quick Play" type mode.

There's a cheater problem. Joined 3 consecutive games, I see the progress bar as a yellow line shoots for first. Then the third game, my neighbour typing like a man out of nightmares and DING! They finish 4 whole sentences in 2 seconds? I definitely expected to run into 150 words a minute people... but not 999 words a minute.

It's an interesting game. Needs protection from these kinds of people. Or i'm garbage with a skill issue. Who knows. I do have an idea though to make the game better.

I would say to fix this issue would be to add a matchmaking system built on the typing speed of each user over time. That way, cheaters with GODLY speeds only compete with other cheaters. Meanwhile, those with the same word type speed are competing with others of the same skill. Challenging and fair.

I want to love this so bad, but after a few rounds there are a number of glaring issues:

- The punishment for mistakes is extremely brutal, and makes no allowance for skilled typists who can feel a mistake before it even hits the screen, and instantly backspace it - which is true of the vast majority of skilled typists. This game basically grates on your brain if that's how you type by never allowing you to do it.

- The text it has you typing starts out normal, but it very quickly turns into memes, misspellings, literally "qwertyuiop asdfghjkl zxcvbnm ---''' zxc zxc zxcbnm bnm bnm asdhjk asdhjk" type stuff that is just miserable to slog through, once again punishing skilled typists by basically blue-shelling them. There's even a section that is literally just a giant block of [i]binary code[/i] - as in, a giant pile of ones and zeroes. Really?

- There is a forced waiting period every few lines of something like ten whole seconds where you just have to sit there and watch the first place advantage you secured for yourself vanish to nothing - five times every round or so, which is aggravating, and once again punishes skilled typists.

Between the forced waiting periods every few lines, the very long mistake animations, and the gibberish it often asks you to type, it is essentially impossible to get into any kind of flow state or rhythm - you're always having to stop, wait, reset, and begin again, over and over again the whole time. It is not fun. 

If you type faster than, say, 60WPM and consider yourself a good typist, this game will take every single possible opportunity to balance against you, punish you for being fast, or otherwise negate your skill to allow slower typists to catch up. I get what they're going for, balance-wise, but it makes the game absolutely miserable for the exact kind of person who is likely to pay for this and keep the community alive long-term.

If this is to be worth purchasing and sticking with as a game, it needs to be a lot more pleasant of an experience for people who are actually skilled at typing, and not treat them like a bug to be ironed out for the sake of hyper-casual players who will not stick with it long term. This is a multiplayer game - you need the diehards to keep the servers alive.

It seems like the intent was to balance out highly skilled typists so they don't just cream the beginners...

[h1]The review[/h1]
I'm a pretty good typer and love typing games, so I decided to give this a shot. I played three times after the tutorial. I forfeited one of these games.

The idea is interesting. The game has potential. The atmosphere and graphics are on point, and the gameplay itself is fun.

But the issue is : if someone is taking a big lead (which happened in my two complete games), you basically have no way to close the gap. And that's because the game has too many "time wasters".

The first time waster, which is the one I think is legit, is making you restart the whole sentence if you make a mistake. It's quick, it's instant, you just waste the time to retype what you already typed.

The second time waster is the mandatory break between section. The total text you have to type is divided in sections, and at the end of each, you have a few seconds where you can't do anything. The sections themselves are fine (they also act as resets for the third time waster), but I think the wait should be removed, or changed. Because said wait seems to be the same for everybody, that prevents you from catching up with the first place.

The third time waster is the worst and should definitelly be removed : the roulette. Each time you make 3 mistakes in one section, you have to play Russian Roulette and risk being eliminated. And the animation *is so damn long*. It feels longer than the mandatory break, you waste so much time, and it makes the gap between you and the others even bigger because it is a wait only those who trigger a roulette suffer. And it feels like a double punishment : you already have to redo the whole line, and then you have to wait super long to be able to get back in the game. The game I forfeited was because I triggered two roulettes so I was basically cooked. In my opinion, the shot should be instant (especially because you can see the guy hold the gun up on your second mistake, so no need to animate him hold the gun up) and not take longer than the line reset when you make a mistake.

In short : because of the mandatory break and the roulette, once someone has one or two sections in advance on you, you pretty much lost. Fighting knowing you have no chance to win is not fun. Better forfeit and start a new lobby than waste time.

As such, even though I love the concept and I see efforts have been poured into this project, I cannot recommend this game in this state.

[h1]Suggestions[/h1]

My first suggestion is to remove the mandatory break and the roulette animation. Just have the black coat man fire immediately without a pause. It will remove some of the drama of the roulette triggering when it's a blank, but it won't remove the shock of being shot if it's a live round and right now it's more frustrating than scary.

My second suggestion is to remove the snowball effect of taking the lead : the leader has too much leeway.
Maybe make it so everyone has to wait each others at the end of each section, so the next section starts with everyone at the same point, and add a bullet to the bottom 50% players' roulette. That way, you still insentize everyone to be one of the quickest as to not get rouletted, which keeps the stress high and still pushes them to make mistake and trigger the roulette, while not having someone who's so obviously in the lead that people cannot catch up. It could be a second play mode, with the current one being a "Quick Play" type mode.

I want to love this so bad, but after a few rounds there are a number of glaring issues:

- The punishment for mistakes is extremely brutal, and makes no allowance for skilled typists who can feel a mistake before it even hits the screen, and instantly backspace it - which is true of the vast majority of skilled typists. This game basically grates on your brain if that's how you type by never allowing you to do it.

- The text it has you typing starts out normal, but it very quickly turns into memes, misspellings, literally "qwertyuiop asdfghjkl zxcvbnm ---''' zxc zxc zxcbnm bnm bnm asdhjk asdhjk" type stuff that is just miserable to slog through, once again punishing skilled typists by basically blue-shelling them. There's even a section that is literally just a giant block of [i]binary code[/i] - as in, a giant pile of ones and zeroes. Really?

- There is a forced waiting period every few lines of something like ten whole seconds where you just have to sit there and watch the first place advantage you secured for yourself vanish to nothing - five times every round or so, which is aggravating, and once again punishes skilled typists.

Between the forced waiting periods every few lines, the very long mistake animations, and the gibberish it often asks you to type, it is essentially impossible to get into any kind of flow state or rhythm - you're always having to stop, wait, reset, and begin again, over and over again the whole time. It is not fun. 

If you type faster than, say, 60WPM and consider yourself a good typist, this game will take every single possible opportunity to balance against you, punish you for being fast, or otherwise negate your skill to allow slower typists to catch up. I get what they're going for, balance-wise, but it makes the game absolutely miserable for the exact kind of person who is likely to pay for this and keep the community alive long-term.

If this is to be worth purchasing and sticking with as a game, it needs to be a lot more pleasant of an experience for people who are actually skilled at typing, and not treat them like a bug to be ironed out for the sake of hyper-casual players who will not stick with it long term.
